answer_html: \(\displaystyle \{ x : x \not= n\pi \}\) where n is an integer.
answer_latex: $\displaystyle \{ x : x \not= n\pi \}$ where \emph{n} is an integer.
hints_html:
What value in the denominator will make a function undefined?

Where is \(\sin (x) = 0\)?
hints_latex: What value in the denominator will make a function undefined?
hints_raw:
What value in the denominator will make a function undefined?
Where is <math>\sin (x) = 0</math>?
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
The function g(x) is undefined wherever the denominator is zero. Thus we need to know where \(\sin(x) = 0\).

Based on the unit circle, we know that \(\sin(x)\) is zero at the angles 0, \(\pi\), 2\(\pi\), 3\(\pi\), ... Thus, these points can not be included in the domain of g.

So our domain is:

\(\displaystyle \{ x : x \not= n\pi \}\) where n is an integer.
sols_latex:
The function \emph{g}(\emph{x}) is undefined wherever the denominator is
zero. Thus we need to know where $\sin(x) = 0$.

Based on the unit circle, we know that $\sin(x)$ is zero at the angles
0, $\pi$, 2$\pi$, 3$\pi$, ... Thus, these points can not be included in the domain
of \emph{g}.

So our domain is:

$\displaystyle \{ x : x \not= n\pi \}$ where \emph{n} is an integer.
sols_raw:
The function ''g''(''x'') is undefined wherever the denominator is zero.  Thus we need to know where <math>\sin(x) = 0</math>.  

Based on the unit circle, we know that <math>\sin(x)</math> is zero at the angles 0, &pi;, 2&pi;, 3&pi;, ...  Thus, these points can not be included in the domain of ''g''.  

So our domain is:

<math> \displaystyle \{ x : x \not= n\pi \}</math> where ''n'' is an integer.
statement_html:
Find the domain of the function

\[\begin{aligned} g(x) = \frac{1}{\sin(x)}\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Find the domain of the function 
: <math>g(x) = \frac{1}{\sin(x)} </math>
